questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with diffuse back pain. Upon examination, there is no limitation of motion in the sacroiliac joints, and the intervertebral disc spaces appear preserved. The cervical spine X-ray reveals flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspects of the vertebral bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. DISH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton , leading to the fusion of affected joints , known as ankylosis . The hallmark radiographic findings in AS are sacroiliitis and syndesmophytes , leading to a "bamboo spine" appearance . However, the intervertebral disc spaces are typically preserved until late in the disease.
  • • Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis:
  • • affects the sacroiliac joints
  • • axial skeleton
  • • fusion of affected joints
  • • ankylosis
  • • radiographic findings
  • • AS are sacroiliitis
  • • syndesmophytes
  • • "bamboo spine" appearance
  • • Option C. Klippel-Feil Syndrome: Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae . It may present with a short neck, limited neck movement, and low hairline. Radiographs would show fused cervical vertebrae, but not the flowing ossifications typical of DISH.
  • • Option C. Klippel-Feil Syndrome:
  • • congenital condition
  • • fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae
  • • Option D. Sprengel Deformity: Sprengel deformity is a congenital condition in which the scapula is abnormally high due to its failure to descend during development . It's not related to spinal pathology and wouldn't show the characteristic findings of DISH on spinal imaging.
  • • Option D. Sprengel Deformity:
  • • congenital condition
  • • scapula is abnormally high
  • • failure to descend during development

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The X-ray findings of flowing ossification along the anterior aspects of the thoracic spine with preserved intervertebral disc spaces in an elderly patient is indicative of DISH , which does not involve the sacroiliac joints.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of back pain and an abnormal curvature of the spine. Physical examination reveals a lateral curvature of the spine with a prominence of the left ribcage. The patient is otherwise healthy, with no other significant medical history. An X-ray of the spine is performed, which of the following angles would be measured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cobb angle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bohler angle: The Bohler angle , or tuber joint angle , is used in orthopedics to assess calcaneal fractures on lateral foot radiographs . It is formed by the intersection of two lines : one drawn from the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus to the highest point of the posterior articular surface and the other from the highest point of the posterior articular surface to the highest point of the posterior aspect of the calcaneus.

  • • highest point of the posterior articular surface
  • • Option B. Gissane angle: Also known as the critical angle , it’s measured on lateral foot radiographs and used to assess calcaneal fractures , similar to the Bohler angle. It's formed by the downward and inward slopes of the calcaneus' superior surfaces.

  • • critical angle

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): DISH is characterized by calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and entheses , the bony attachments of tendons and ligaments . It commonly affects the thoracic spine and is associated with diabetes and obesity. It does not typically cause discoloration in the eyes or pinna.
  • • Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis):
  • • calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments
  • • entheses
  • • bony attachments of tendons and ligaments
  • • Option B. Fluorosis: Dental and skeletal fluorosis result from chronic exposure to high levels of fluoride and can lead to mottling of teeth and calcification of ligaments . While it can cause skeletal changes, the blackish discoloration of the eyes and pinna is not a feature of fluorosis.
  • • Option B. Fluorosis:
  • • Dental
  • • skeletal fluorosis
  • • chronic exposure to high levels of fluoride
  • • mottling of teeth
  • • calcification of ligaments
  • • Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory disease that can cause fusion of the spine , leading to a characteristic bamboo spine appearance on X-ray . It does not, however, cause hyperpigmentation of the ears and eyes.
  • • Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis:
  • • inflammatory disease
  • • cause fusion of the spine
  • • bamboo spine appearance on X-ray

  • ➤ The presence of blackish discoloration of the eyes and pinna , along with the radiographic finding of intervertebral disc calcification , is indicative of alkaptonuria , a disorder of homogentisic acid metabolism leading to ochronosis and potential joint degeneration .

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with a slow-growing, painless mass on her upper back that has been present for several years. The mass is soft and mobile, with a doughy texture. Physical examination reveals a 5 cm subcutaneous mass that is well-circumscribed and non-tender. There is no erythema, warmth, or fluctuance. The patient is otherwise healthy, with no other significant medical history. The clinician makes a diagnosis of lipoma. Which of the following statements would be true about the lesion on imaging?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypodense on CT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Anechoic on US: On ultrasound , lipomas are usually hyperechoic or have mixed echogenicity due to the presence of fat and fibrous tissue . Anechoic would imply the lesion is fluid-filled, which is not characteristic of lipomas.

  • • ultrasound
  • • lipomas
  • • hyperechoic
  • • have mixed echogenicity
  • • presence of fat and fibrous tissue
  • • Option C. Hypo-intense on T1-MRI: This is not true for lipomas; they are actually hyperintense on T1-weighted MRI images because fat has a high signal on T1 .
  • • Option C. Hypo-intense on T1-MRI:
  • • actually hyperintense on T1-weighted MRI images
  • • fat has a high signal on T1
  • • Option D. Hypo-intense on T2-MRI: Again, this is incorrect for lipomas . Lipomas are usually also hyperintense on T2-weighted MRI images because fat has a high signal on T2 .
  • • Option D. Hypo-intense on T2-MRI:
  • • incorrect for lipomas
  • • Lipomas
  • • hyperintense on T2-weighted MRI images
  • • fat has a high signal on T2

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of a slow-growing mass on his thigh that has been present for several months. He reports that the mass is painless but has been increasing in size. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender mass measuring approximately 5 cm in diameter. The overlying skin is normal, with no signs of inflammation or discoloration. Investigation of choice for soft tissue sarcoma is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. MRI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. CT: Computed Tomography (CT) can be useful for evaluating STS , especially to assess for metastatic disease . However, it is not the best modality for local staging due to its lower contrast resolution compared to MRI.
  • • Option A. CT:
  • • useful for evaluating STS
  • • assess for metastatic disease
  • • Option C. Ultrasound: While ultrasound can be used to differentiate cystic from solid masses and can be useful for guiding biopsies , it is not the investigation of choice for the assessment or staging of STS. Its utility is limited due to the operator-dependent nature and limited field of view.
  • • Option C. Ultrasound:
  • • used to differentiate cystic from solid masses
  • • useful for guiding biopsies
  • • Option D. X-ray: Plain radiographs (X-ray) have limited use in evaluating soft tissue masses , as they are best for assessing bones . Some STS may calcify and thus be visible on X-ray, but most will not be adequately visualized with this modality.
  • • Option D. X-ray:
  • • limited use in evaluating soft tissue masses
  • • best for assessing bones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the evaluation of soft tissue sarcomas , MRI is the imaging modality of choice due to its superior contrast resolution , which aids in detailed local staging and surgical planning .

questions.text: A patient presented with neck pain and rigidity, which gets relieved after bathing in hot water and also after exercise. Cervical X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Spondylolisthesis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Spondylosis: Spondylosis refers to degenerative changes in the spine , including disc degeneration and osteophyte formation . While it can cause neck pain , the typical X-ray findings would be narrowed disc spaces, bony spurs, and possible facet joint hypertrophy, not a vertebral slip.
  • • Option B. Spondylosis:
  • • degenerative changes in the spine
  • • disc degeneration
  • • osteophyte formation
  • • cause neck pain
  • • Option C. Compression Fracture: A compression fracture occurs when a vertebral body is compressed anteriorly , leading to a wedge-shaped vertebra on lateral X-ray . It typically results from osteoporosis or trauma, and the classic sign is a loss of height at the anterior aspect of the vertebral body.
  • • Option C. Compression Fracture:
  • • vertebral body is compressed anteriorly
  • • wedge-shaped vertebra
  • • lateral X-ray
  • • Option D. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis itself doesn't have a specific sign on an X-ray , but it predisposes to fractures , including compression fractures . It is usually diagnosed with a bone density scan (DEXA) and might show generalized low bone density on X-ray.
  • • Option D. Osteoporosis:
  • • doesn't have a specific sign
  • • X-ray
  • • predisposes to fractures
  • • compression fractures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral cervical X-ray showing a forward shift of a vertebral body is indicative of spondylolisthesis , often associated with a pars interarticularis defect , which can be symptomatically relieved by heat and exercise due to muscle relaxation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of acute onset pain and swelling in his right big toe. He reports that the pain is excruciating and is preventing him from walking. Physical examination reveals erythema and tenderness in the affected joint, with limited range of motion. X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Gout

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is characterized by joint pain and stiffness , primarily in weight-bearing joints , due to cartilage breakdown . X-ray findings typically include joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts. It usually does not present with the acute, severe inflammation seen in this case.
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis:
  • • joint pain
  • • stiffness
  • • weight-bearing joints
  • • cartilage breakdown
  • • Option B. Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes symmetrical joint inflammation . X-ray findings might show soft tissue swelling, osteopenia near the joint (periarticular osteopenia), uniform joint space narrowing, and marginal erosions, but it is more chronic and less localized than the presentation described.
  • • Option B. Rheumatoid Arthritis:
  • • chronic autoimmune condition
  • • symmetrical joint inflammation
  • • Option C. Pseudo Gout: Pseudo gout, or calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), can cause acute monoarticular arthritis , but X-ray findings often show calcification in the cartilage (chondrocalcinosis), which is not described in the provided X-ray.
  • • Option C. Pseudo Gout:
  • • calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease
  • • cause acute monoarticular arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presentation of acute onset pain and swelling in the big toe , with X-ray findings of erosions and marked destruction of the metatarsal-phalangeal and interphalangeal joints , is typical of gout , often associated with "rat-bite" erosions or Martel's sign.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain and stiffness that has been ongoing for the past few months. She reports that the pain is worse in the morning and is relieved by movement throughout the day. She also reports swelling in her hands and feet, along with fatigue and weight loss. On physical examination, there is synovial swelling in multiple joints, particularly the small joints of the hands and feet. There is also tenderness and limited range of motion in these joints. Laboratory tests show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) level. The X-ray of the hand is shown here. The patient shown below most likely has?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Rheumatoid arthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis would cause subchondral sclerosis and the formation of marginal osteophytes but not erosions . Osteoarthritis in the hand typically involves the distal interphalangeal joints.
  • • Option A.
  • • Osteoarthritis

  • • formation of marginal osteophytes
  • • not erosions
  • • Option C. Jaccoud’s arthropathy is associated with SLE wherein there are deformities typical in RA , but without any erosions.
  • • Option C.
  • • Jaccoud’s arthropathy
  • • SLE
  • • deformities typical in RA
  • • Option D. Avascular necrosis of the hip is the most common site for osteonecrosis due to a combination of precarious blood supply and high loading when standing . It could lead to secondary osteoarthritis, but that is unlikely in the hand and would never involve this many joint.
  • • Option D.
  • • Avascular necrosis
  • • hip is the most common site for osteonecrosis
  • • combination of precarious blood supply
  • • high loading when standing

questions.text: A 70‐year‐old male presents with right wrist pain and the following radiograph. Which of the following is the most likely primary tumor if this is proven to be metastatic?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Renal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of the sympathetic nervous system that primarily affects children , usually under the age of 5 . It can metastasize to the bone, presenting as lytic or mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions, but it would be extremely uncommon for it to be the source of metastasis in a 70-year-old.
  • • Option B. Neuroblastoma:
  • • malignancy of the sympathetic nervous system
  • • primarily affects children
  • • under the age of 5
  • • Option C. Prostate Carcinoma: Prostate cancer typically metastasizes to the bone in a blastic fashion , meaning that the lesions it creates are dense and sclerotic , not lytic. While patients with prostate cancer can present with bone pain, the radiographic appearance of their metastases usually differs from what is shown in this patient's radiograph.
  • • Option C. Prostate Carcinoma:
  • • metastasizes to the bone in a blastic fashion
  • • lesions it creates are dense and sclerotic
  • • Option D. Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma: Papillary thyroid carcinoma primarily metastasizes to regional lymph nodes and, less commonly , to distant sites like the lungs and bones . When it does metastasize to bone, it can cause lytic lesions, but follicular thyroid carcinoma is more commonly associated with osseous metastases than papillary subtype.
  • • Option D. Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma:
  • • metastasizes to regional lymph nodes
  • • less commonly
  • • distant sites like the lungs and bones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of an expansile , lytic lesion in the distal radius with pathologic fracture in a 70-year-old patient is most consistent with metastatic renal cell carcinoma , which frequently manifests as hypervascular, aggressive lytic lesions in the bone.

questions.text: Which condition is associated with a "rotting fence post" appearance of the femur on radiographic imaging?

  • • fibrous tissue

  • • Option C. Paget’s Disease: Paget's disease of bone involves a disordered bone remodeling process , with mixed lytic and sclerotic phases . Characteristic findings include thickened cortical bone with an enlarged, "cotton wool" appearance. It does not cause a "rotting fence post" appearance.

  • • disordered bone remodeling process

  • • sclerotic phases
  • • Option D. Fracture Neck of Femur: A femoral neck fracture is a break in the proximal aspect of the femur . While it can lead to irregularity of the bone contour, it does not resemble the changes seen in rickets or hyperparathyroidism, and it would not be described as a "rotting fence post" appearance.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with severe back pain that has been gradually worsening over the past few weeks. The patient reports that the pain is worse at night and is not relieved by rest or over-the-counter pain medications. He also reports significant weight loss over the past few months. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation over the thoracic and lumbar spine. There is also mild weakness in the lower extremities and a loss of sensation below the level of the umbilicus. The X-ray of the spine is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vertebral metastasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pott spine: Pott disease, or spinal tuberculosis , can cause destruction of the vertebral bodies leading to kyphosis and potentially an abscess formation . While it may present with back pain and systemic symptoms, it typically also includes a history of exposure or risk factors for tuberculosis.
  • • Option A. Pott spine:
  • • spinal tuberculosis
  • • cause destruction of the vertebral bodies
  • • kyphosis
  • • abscess formation
  • • Option B. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves the dispersion of bony fragments due to a high-energy axial load injury . It usually presents acutely after trauma and typically doesn't cause progressive symptoms over weeks to months without a history of major trauma.
  • • Option B. Burst fracture:
  • • dispersion of bony fragments
  • • high-energy axial load injury
  • • Option C. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis may lead to compression fractures of the spine , which can cause back pain and height loss . However, the clinical presentation of gradual severe pain, weight loss, and neurological deficits is not typical of primary osteoporosis.
  • • Option C. Osteoporosis:
  • • lead to compression fractures of the spine
  • • cause back pain
  • • height loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with severe, progressive back pain , unrelieved by rest , with systemic symptoms such as weight loss , and neurological deficits , along with radiographic evidence of the "winking owl" sign , vertebral metastasis should be highly suspected.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with chronic low back pain for the past several months. The pain is worse in the morning and improves with activity. He also reports stiffness in his lower back that lasts for several hours and decreased flexibility. He has a family history of inflammatory arthritis. On physical examination, he has limited lumbar spine mobility and tenderness to palpation. Lab tests reveal elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). MRI of the spine and pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ankylosing spondylitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. DISH: DISH is a non-inflammatory condition characterized by calcification and ossification of the spinal ligaments and entheses . It does not typically present with significant bone marrow edema or the erosive changes seen in sacroiliitis.
  • • Option B. DISH:
  • • non-inflammatory condition
  • • calcification and ossification of the spinal ligaments
  • • entheses
  • • Option C. Fluorosis: Fluorosis is caused by excessive fluoride intake and affects bones and teeth , leading to sclerosis and calcification of the ligaments , but it does not typically present with the inflammatory back pain or sacroiliitis seen in the MRI.
  • • Option C. Fluorosis:
  • • excessive fluoride intake
  • • affects bones
  • • teeth
  • • sclerosis and calcification of the ligaments
  • • Option D. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): RA is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects peripheral joints and can cause inflammation in the spine . However, the MRI findings of sacroiliitis are more indicative of AS than RA.
  • • Option D. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA):
  • • autoimmune disease
  • • affects peripheral joints
  • • cause inflammation in the spine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with chronic back pain and stiffness , family history of inflammatory arthritis , elevated inflammatory markers , and MRI findings of sacroiliitis , the most likely diagnosis is ankylosing spondylitis .

Swan Neck Deformity: Swan neck deformity is characterized by hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers , commonly seen in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis. questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with a history of progressive pain and stiffness in his right arm and hand for several years. On physical examination, he has thickening of the bones of his right arm and hand, with palpable bony ridges and irregularities. The affected limb also appears larger than the contralateral side. X-rays is shown below. There is no history of trauma or infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Melorheostosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteopetrosis: Osteopetrosis is a group of disorders characterized by increased bone density due to defective osteoclast resorption . The bones appear uniformly sclerotic, and the condition is typically bilateral and symmetrical, which is not consistent with the patient's unilateral presentation and the X-ray findings.
  • • Option A. Osteopetrosis:
  • • group of disorders
  • • increased bone density
  • • defective osteoclast resorption
  • • Option B. Fluorosis: Fluorosis results from chronic fluoride poisoning , leading to sclerosis of bones and calcification of ligaments . The skeletal changes are usually generalized and diffuse, rather than the linear pattern seen on the X-ray.
  • • Option B. Fluorosis:
  • • chronic fluoride poisoning
  • • leading to sclerosis of bones
  • • calcification of ligaments
  • • Option D. Paget's Disease: Paget's disease of bone involves abnormal bone remodeling with mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic phases . It can present with bone pain, enlargement, and deformity. However, the "dripping candle wax" appearance on X-ray is not typical of Paget’s disease.
  • • Option D. Paget's Disease:
  • • abnormal bone remodeling
  • • mixed osteolytic
  • • osteosclerotic phases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presentation of progressive pain and stiffness in a limb , with palpable bony irregularities and an X-ray showing linear hyperostosis with a "dripping candle wax" pattern, is indicative of Melorheostosis . This rare condition often affects only one limb and leads to progressive sclerosis of cortical bone.

  • ➤ stiffness in a limb
  • ➤ palpable bony irregularities
  • ➤ X-ray showing linear hyperostosis

questions.text: A 2-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of short stature. The parents are of average height and deny any family history of dwarfism. On physical examination, the child has a large head with a prominent forehead, short arms and legs, and a broad, flattened nasal bridge. His fingers are short and stubby, and he has a prominent belly. X-rays is shown here. . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Achondroplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis characterized by developmental delay , corneal clouding , and organomegaly . Skeletal abnormalities include dysostosis multiplex, which differs from the findings in this X-ray.
  • • Option A. Hurler Syndrome:
  • • mucopolysaccharidosis
  • • developmental delay
  • • corneal clouding
  • • organomegaly
  • • Option B. Marfan Syndrome: Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder presenting with tall stature , arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis , and cardiovascular abnormalities , which does not correlate with the clinical features or X-ray findings of this patient.
  • • Option B. Marfan Syndrome:
  • • connective tissue disorder
  • • tall stature
  • • arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis
  • • cardiovascular abnormalities
  • • Option D. Turner Syndrome: Turner syndrome affects females and presents with short stature , shield chest , and gonadal dysgenesis . This syndrome does not typically present with the skeletal findings observed in the X-ray.
  • • Option D. Turner Syndrome:
  • • affects females
  • • presents with short stature
  • • shield chest
  • • gonadal dysgenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of short stature , macrocephaly with frontal bossing , rhizomelic limb shortening , and the characteristic "champagne glass pelvis" on X-ray is diagnostic of Achondroplasia , which is a genetic disorder resulting in the most common form of disproportionate short stature.

  • ➤ "champagne glass pelvis" on X-ray

questions.text: A 9-month-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of poor growth and developmental delay. The parents report that the child has been exclusively breastfed. On physical examination, the child is small for his age. There is also a prominent anterior fontanelle on the child's skull. questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with a 4-week history of worsening left leg pain. The pain is constant, dull, and aching in nature. The patient denies any trauma or injury to the leg. On examination, there is tenderness over calf with swelling. There is no warmth or erythema. X-ray is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  • • presents with a mixed lytic
  • • sclerotic pattern
  • • exhibit a sunburst periosteal reaction
  • • Option C. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma is a cancer of cartilage cells , usually occurring in adults. It often shows a stippled or popcorn-like calcification on imaging .
  • • Option C. Chondrosarcoma:
  • • cancer of cartilage cells
  • • occurring in adults.
  • • stippled or popcorn-like calcification on imaging
  • • Option D. Fibrosarcoma: Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor of fibroblasts and presents with a lytic pattern on imaging but lacks the characteristic periosteal reaction seen in Ewing sarcoma.
  • • Option D. Fibrosarcoma:
  • • malignant tumor of fibroblasts
  • • presents with a lytic pattern
  • • imaging

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 2-month history of left hip pain that is exacerbated by weight-bearing activities. He denies any history of trauma, infection, or steroid use. On examination, there is tenderness over the left hip joint with limited range of motion. What is the best imaging modality to diagnose the patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. MRI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. CT Scan: A CT scan can provide detailed images of bone and can detect subchondral fractures and changes in bone structure . However, it is less sensitive than MRI for early detection of AVN because it may not capture the earliest changes in bone marrow.
  • • Option B. CT Scan:
  • • detailed images of bone
  • • detect subchondral fractures
  • • changes in bone structure
  • • Option C. Bone Scan: Bone scans involve the use of radioactive material to evaluate bone metabolism . They are sensitive for detecting bone changes but lack specificity. They might be positive in AVN but can also be positive in many other bone pathologies; hence, they are not as diagnostic as MRI.
  • • Option C. Bone Scan:
  • • use of radioactive material
  • • evaluate bone metabolism
  • • Option D. PET Scan: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scans are typically used to detect cancer , assess cancer response to treatment , and evaluate brain function . They are not the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing AVN.
  • • Option D. PET Scan:
  • • used to detect cancer
  • • assess cancer response
  • • treatment
  • • evaluate brain function

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with hip pain and clinical suspicion of AVN , MRI is the best initial imaging study due to its high sensitivity and specificity for detecting early marrow changes , which precede the development of subchondral fractures and collapse .

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of increasing headaches and hearing loss. He reports no history of trauma or infection and denies any recent changes in medication. On examination, there is tenderness over the frontal and parietal bones with palpable bony deformities. Serum alkaline phosphatase levels are elevated. X-ray of the skull is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Paget’s disease
